courses.subject: GRON
courses.title: Ageing, Health and Society
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a basic understanding of population ageing from the sociological perspectives. It focuses on the development of a multi-dimensional understanding of the factors that affect the health of older adults and the ways that socio-demographic changes shape societal attitudes towards old age. Emphasis is placed on discussions of the impact of population ageing on the social and health care needs of a society.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Analyze the global trends of population ageing and their impact on health care, social and economic issues in society.
2. Develop theoretical understandings in the societal changes in ageing.
3. Justify the social construction of "age" and "ageing process" in individual and social contexts.
4. Synthesize the impact of population ageing on health and social care needs in society.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction: Orienting concepts and related issues
Social forces and health patterning in ageing
Classical sociological understandings and social theories of ageing
Social constructionism and ageing
Changing roles and relationships over life course
Addressing Ageism - Prevention and Intervention
Ageing and social policy
Ageing as a women’s issue
Foucauldian analysis of ageing
Global ageing: Changing demographics and epidemiological transition
(Bio)medicalisation of ageing

courses.title: Basic Care in Gerontology

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706

courses.description: This course aims to equip students with foundational knowledge and essential skills to address the basic care needs of older people. Emphasis is placed on promoting an understanding of the basic principles of care to help older people to meet their basic life needs. Fundamental concepts such as nutrition, exercise, oral care, basic hygiene care, communication, and psychosocial care are also covered.

1. Explain the purposes and content of various geriatric assessment tools.
2. Demonstrate the ability to conduct comprehensive assessments to determine the biopsychosocial needs and conditions of older people and their families.

4. Describe the principles and demonstrate the ability to perform basic skills for providing care to older people safely and effectively.
5. Discuss the special issues relating to the provision of basic care to older people. The issues include infection control, occupational safety, and inter-professional practice.

4. Discuss the concepts and strategies to build an age-friendly community.

courses.title: Psychology in Ageing: Theories and Application
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a basic understanding of the concepts and theoretical approaches of psychology relevant to ageing and aged care in various care settings. Emphasis is placed on the application of these concepts to understand individual and group behaviour and the health and social care needs of individuals and groups.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care

courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Discuss the psychological changes throughout the lifespan.
2. Examine influences of motivation, emotion, learning, memory and personality on individual and group behaviour of older people in various health and social care settings.
3. Develop sensitivity over approaches and demonstrate effective communication skills of enhancing psychological well-being in older people
4. Discuss the common major life events and challenges among older people and integrate psychological theories to explain the impact on psychological well-being.

courses.subject: GRON
courses.title: Chronic Disease Management in Ageing
courses.description: This course aims to enhance the understanding of the complexities of care for people with chronic diseases. An interdisciplinary approach for the chronic disease management from health and social perspectives will be applied. It also focuses on the design of care which directly addresses the physical and psychosocial consequences of chronic diseases, especially for older people and their caregivers. Basic principles and concepts of community-based care and rehabilitation, and the importance of empowerment of patients as well as families in self-management of chronic illnesses in a community setting will be covered.

1. Summarize the physical and psychosocial impacts of chronic diseases especially on older people
2. Identify the roles of different healthcare disciplines in managing major chronic diseases

4. Discuss the self-care models for chronic disease management and strategies to empower people managing their diseases
5. Discuss the types and roles of community resources in supporting people living with chronic conditions.
6. Describe the role of public health or community health practitioners in disease management

William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 706

courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a comprehensive overview of the pathophysiological, behavioural and psychosocial aspects of dementia. Emphasis is placed on equipping students with the knowledge and skills required to prevent, detect and manage dementia in older people. The course also highlights the roles of family caregivers, multidisciplinary care teams, and community care services in managing dementia.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Describe the pathogenesis, risk factors, types, and stages of dementia.
2. Describe the comprehensive health and social assessment for dementia.
3. Discuss the physical, cognitive, behavioural and psychosocial manifestations of dementia.
4. Describe the pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions for dementia.
5. Discuss the evidence-based care in managing dementia in the community, rehabilitative and long-term care settings.
6. Discuss the interventions to maintain and promote brain health.
7. Discuss the role of an interprofessional team approach in the care of older people with dementia and their caregivers and families.
8. Discuss the role of informal caregivers in the care of older people with dementia.
9. Discuss the role of health and social care services in the care of older people with dementia.

courses.subject: GRON
courses.title: Aged Care Service Planning and Delivery Models
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the principles, concepts and skills involved in planning and delivering aged care services in a variety of aged care settings, including community, rehabilitative and residential care settings locally and globally. The basic concepts covered include ageing in place, social involvement and participation, integrated community-based care, the home care delivery model, discharge planning, innovative practice, interdisciplinary and cross-sectoral service coordination, and the residential care home accreditation system. The course highlights the notion of health and social care partnership, and a multi-dimensional perspective is adopted to facilitate students’ examination on the service planning and delivery model for the provision of community, rehabilitative and residential care services to older people.

courses.subject: GRON
courses.title: Innovations and Evidence-based Practice for Aged Care Services
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with an overview of the research methods used in examining health and social care issues, and to equip them with knowledge of evidence-based practice with special reference to gerontology. The course also examines the impacts of the changing health and social care context on the delivery of aged care services, and introduces the evidence-based innovative models of aged care service delivery.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Describe the range of theoretical, methodological and ethical issues associated with the development and implementation of evidence-base practice in aged care services.
2. Critically appraise the scientific quality and contextual relevance of research evidence, and effectively apply such knowledge to develop innovations in aged care services.
3. Demonstrate a critical understanding of the use of specific research methods and techniques to address the knowledge gap in aged care services.
4. Describe the frameworks to identify and analyses complex internal and external factors in transferring evidence to inform the development of innovations in aged care services.
5. Critically appraise the quality of innovative models in aged care service delivery using a scientific and systematic evidence-based approach.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. An overview of research process and evidence-based practice in knowledge development.
2. Formulation of research problems, questions and hypotheses in gerontological care practice.
3. Searching and reviewing literature.
4. Quantitative research in gerontology: study design, issues of validity, sampling design, data collection methods, data analyses and interpretation.
5. Qualitative research in gerontology: sampling design, data collection methods and issues of reliability and validity on data collection, data analysis and interpretation.
6. Ethical issues in conducting gerontological research.
7. Translating and integrating scientific evidence to aged care services.

courses.subject: GRON
courses.title: Death, Dying and End-of-life Care
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a basic understanding of the concepts and principles of end-of-life care, and to equip them with essential knowledge and skills in the provision of hospice care and advance care planning to older people with terminal illness sufferers and their families.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Be familiar with the development, theories and intervention approaches related to death, dying and end-of-life care.
2. Examine effective communication skills related to issues of death and dying, considering societal and geographic factors.​3.
3. Critically analyse current policies and practices in the field of end-of-life care, and propose innovative approaches and strategies for improving the quality of care and support provided to individuals and their families facing the end of life
4. Discuss the value and attitudes toward life and death issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 
Introduction: Orienting concepts and related issues
2. 
Death theories and implementation in end-of-life care
3. 
Development and principles of end-of-life care
4. 
Management of clients with terminal illness
5. 
Communication and counselling skills in end-of-life care
6. 
Global experiences and challenges of end-of-life care
7. 
End-of-life care services in Asia – overview
8. 
End-of-life care services in Hong Kong – frontline experience sharing
9. 
Site visit
10. 
Advanced care planning (ACP) programme and evaluation
11. 
Ethical considerations in end-of-life care
12. 
Funeral & bereavement care

courses.subject: GRON
courses.title: Gerontological Practicum
courses.description: The aim of this clinical practicum is to provide students with clinical practice opportunities to apply related principles, concepts and theories for planning and delivering aged care services in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings. Students are facilitated to develop their knowledge of and skills in service planning, coordination and delivery in these settings.

Capstone Course
Experiential Learning Course
Internship
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Discuss the models for planning and delivering aged care services in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings.
2. Effectively communicate with older clients, their families, and health and social care team members in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings.
3. Apply the knowledge and skills of health and social sciences in ageing to identify the needs of older people and deliver high quality aged care services in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings.
4. Demonstrate an understanding of the principles and skills in coordinating multi-disciplinary care and optimizing inter-sectoral collaboration for the delivery of aged care services in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings.
5. Apply legal and ethical principles in delivering high quality aged care in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings.
courses.course_syllabus: This clinical course facilitates development and application of knowledge and skills of health and social aged care in community, rehabilitative and residential care settings. Students are expected to discuss the service planning and delivery models adopted in these aged care settings, to demonstrate effective communication skills, to develop knowledge and skills for assessing health and social care needs, coordinating multi- disciplinary care and optimizing inter-sectoral collaboration in the delivery of aged care services, and to discuss legal and ethical issues in community aged care services.
